page.title: 02BUILD'S IN THE GRIN'TON AREA
page.content: The general impression is of stone constructions,and roughcast rendering of whole walls or panels.The farm buildings and field walls are sand- stone,with limestone towards Ch'burn. Original roofs are of stone and slate; renovation often of grey slate.Early cottages are of stone or roughcast rendered.Terraced rows are of stone; later of brick and rendered above.Pre- war detached/semi-detached houses and bungalows are brick or stone rendered above.Post-war rows and estates use various coloured bricks for blending into the landscape.Later buildings are often faced with re-constituted or re- used stone.Roof tiles are often factory made.Chimneys are on most roofs.Cotton mills,churches and schools are standing in each village.There are about20 listed buildings of special architectural or historic interest.
